theme.title: The eighth note
theme.para: The next figure we are going to study is the eighth note (also called 'quaver' in British English). Its symbols are shown in the following score, and are like a quarter note with a flag added to its stem:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (spacer 40) (n c5 e) (spacer 40) (n f4 e) (spacer 40) (barline end) )))

theme.para: Many times eighth notes are drawn beamed:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (spacer 30) (n c4 e g+)(n g4 e g-)(n b4 e g+)(n e5 e g-)(barline double) (n c5 e g+)(n e5 e)(n b4 e)(n d4 e g-)(barline double) (n e4 e g+)(n g4 e)(n f4 e)(n a4 e g-) (barline end) )))

theme.para: Beaming is not done at random or by personal taste. The rules for beaming depend on the time signature.

One quarter note equals two eighth notes and one quarter rest equals two eighth rests. So in 2/4 time signature an eighth note or rest gets half a beats, and, therefore, there are two eighth notes in a beat. So in 2/4 they are usually drawn beamed, occupying a beat.
In this lesson we will start the study of rhythms with eighth notes. Play the following score and take note of the new rhythmic patterns introduced in each measure:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 2 4) (n g4 q)(n g4 e g+)(n g4 e g-)(barline) (n g4 e g+)(n g4 e g-)(n g4 q)(barline) (n g4 e g+)(n g4 e)(n g4 e)(n g4 e g-)(barline) (n g4 q)(r q) (barline end) )))
